#Text=Tara Ruttley
#Text=Tara Melaine Ruttley
#Text=( born 1975/1976 ) is Associate Program Scientist for the International Space Station ( ISS ) at NASA ' s Johnson Space Center in Houston , Texas .

#Text=Until 2007 , she was lead hardware engineer for the ISS Health Maintenance System , leading a team of engineers whose job was to provide reliable medical equipment that kept astronauts healthy in orbit .
#Text=She subsequently served as the lead hardware engineer for the ISS Human Research Facility . [ 1 ] [ 2 ] [ 3 ]
#Text=She served as an aquanaut on the NASA Extreme Environment Mission Operations 6 ( NEEMO 6 ) crew in July 2004 . [ 4 ] [ 5 ]
#Text=Education
#Text=Ruttley was born in Houma , Louisiana , and raised in Lafayette , Louisiana .
#Text=Since Ruttley had always loved biology and physiology , she started her educational journey focusing on a career in life sciences .

#Text=She received a Bachelor of Science degree in Biology and a Master of Science in Mechanical Engineering with an emphasis in Biomedical Engineering from Colorado State University ( CSU ) , where she was a member of the Class of 2000 . [ 2 ] [ 3 ] [ 6 ]
#Text=She also received a Ph. D in Neuroscience in 2007 from University of Texas Medical Branch at Galveston . [ 2 ] [ 7 ]
#Text=Ruttley was a McNair Scholar at CSU . [ 7 ] [ 8 ]
#Text=At CSU , Ruttley became involved with the Colorado Space Grant Consortium and the student branch of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics ( AIAA ) .
#Text=As an undergraduate , and through her participation in student design conferences , she became more interested in the hardware aspects of maintaining optimal crew health in space .
#Text=Ruttley soon realized the importance of an interdisciplinary approach to designing hardware for crew health , so she pursued her master 's degree in Mechanical Engineering . [ 3 ]
#Text=Ruttley also belonged to the American Society of Mechanical Engineers and Sigma Xi while attending CSU . [ 9 ]

#Text=Ruttley 's master 's thesis was the testing of a novel gravity-independent resistive exercise device , the Constant Force Resistive Exercise Unit ( CFREU ) , which she had developed in collaboration with CSU 's AIAA student design team .
#Text=The team had tested one version of the machine in microgravity aboard NASA ' s KC-135 aircraft .
#Text=They subsequently received a $ 70,000 contract from NASA to develop an improved prototype .
#Text=Ruttley and her husband , Paul Colosky , patented the CFREU design when they graduated from CSU . [ 3 ] [ 7 ] [ 9 ]
#Text=NASA career
#Text=Ruttley received an offer to work for NASA 's Biomedical Systems Division upon graduation .
#Text=She came to work for NASA in January 2001 , where her first project was developing a detector for the presence of hydrazine on astronauts ' space suits after EVAs from the ISS .
#Text=She went on to become a project engineer for the exercise bicycle currently on the ISS . [ 3 ] [ 7 ]
#Text=Ruttley subsequently served as lead hardware engineer for the ISS Human Research Facility , and later became Associate Program Scientist for the ISS . [ 1 ] [ 7 ] [ 10 ]
#Text=In 2010 , Ruttley responded to criticisms of the cost of the ISS , saying , " I think those who are naysayers have n't given us a chance — have n't given us enough time to show what we can do .

#Text=In a 2011 interview , Ruttley offered reassurance to scientists concerned that the end of the Space Shuttle program would interfere with ISS research projects , saying ,  If you have an investigation you want to do on the space station , we will get you there .
